comments:
RSE needs to recover from problems much much more reliable. Unfortunately RSE is storing persistent data within the workspace instead of .metadata (where the data would belong anyway). If a user now by accident or by cleaning up his workspace directory and don't know what the RemoteSystem* folder means, is deleting them, RSE must be clever enough to recreate them on next startup. Currently RSE just fails with a lot of exceptions like below. As a result of this, all created remote systems are gone (which would be ok because the user deleted the files) including the "Local" system which is bad because it should be detected that is has to be recreated (as it is done on first launch). The "Local" system node must be available no matter from what a mess RSE might have started up.

Very good point. Although the user messed it up, the system should gracefully recover or the user is lost with an unusable system, not knowing what to do.

In the long run, some of this may be fixed by improving the persistence provider scheme as part of the plan items on bug 170932. But this may happen only after 2.0, while I'd think this bug should be addressed for 2.0.

Let's add some concrete cases that are also testable:

(1) Quit RSE, delete or rename "RemoteSystemsConnections" project, restart.
    --> Shows the exceptions you mentioned, "Local" is missing.
    Expected behavior: show a warning (PDE Errorlog should be fine) and
    re-create empty RemoteSystemsConnections like on initial start.

(2) While RSE is running, close the "RemoteSystemsConnections" project.
    (i.e. in Resource perspective, disable the filter and close the project).
    Create a new connection "SSH Only", select Shells subsystem launch shell.
    --> No error is shown but shell does not start.
    Expected behavior: show an error or warning when the persistent storage
    can not be accessed because the project is closed. Re-open the project.

(3) Invalid data or file system access error in "RemoteSystemsConnections"
    project, e.g. due to file system full. Didn't test this scenario, but
    expected behavior is to show an error as early as possible and gracefully
    recover.

Do you agree with the descriptions and expected behaviors?
Do you see other concrete scenarios that can/should also be tested?
Can you give an order of priority for the various cases? [mine would be 1>2>3]
Could you contribute Unit Tests for some cases?

> Do you agree with the descriptions and expected behaviors?
I agree.

> Do you see other concrete scenarios that can/should also be tested?
There is one other possible case to think about. What if the workspace is read-only? RSE should be still usable even with the the persistence gone. I can remember that we have dealt with such use-cases for our product already.

> Can you give an order of priority for the various cases? [mine would be 1>2>3]
Mine would be absolutly the same order.

>Could you contribute Unit Tests for some cases?
At least for (1) I think I can provide a unit test.

Created an attachment (id=57995)
Patch is addressing case (1)

(In reply to comment #2)
> There is one other possible case to think about. What if the workspace is
> read-only? RSE should be still usable even with the the persistence gone.
> I can remember that we have dealt with such use-cases for our product.

Can you elaborate? I suppose that Eclipse would also misbehave if .metadata is not writable at all, so do you think about a workspace with existing .metadata but opened from a read-only file system? What's the exact scenario you have in mind, what would be the expected behavior, and what's the rank in priority?

Thanks for the patch, this seems to fix the most prominent problem already.
Dave can you review and apply this?

If the RemoteSystemsConnections project is deleted before the workspace is started this change correctly rebuilds the RemoteSystemsConnections project and establishes the Local host. There is still a callback logged as a result.

If the project is deleted from the resource navigator while the workbench is running then callbacks are printed to the console if any changes are attempted to be persisted. This is caused by the lack of checks in the RSEPersistenceManager.
org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.ResourceException: Resource '/RemoteSystemsConnections/dom.properties/PRF.daneel_0/FP.local.files_0' does not exist.
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.checkExists(Resource.java:310)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.checkAccessible(Resource.java:193)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Container.members(Container.java:181)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Container.members(Container.java:164)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.persistence.PropertyFileProvider.removeFolders(PropertyFileProvider.java:197)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.persistence.PropertyFileProvider.saveNode(PropertyFileProvider.java:182)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.persistence.PropertyFileProvider.saveNode(PropertyFileProvider.java:177)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.persistence.PropertyFileProvider.saveRSEDOM(PropertyFileProvider.java:130)
	at org.eclipse.rse.internal.persistence.SaveRSEDOMJob.runInWorkspace(SaveRSEDOMJob.java:45)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.InternalWorkspaceJob.run(InternalWorkspaceJob.java:38)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

The fix should be to request SystemResourcesManager to get the project instead of accessing it directly, but the persistence manager is in core and the resources manager is in the ui plugin. This is due to be moved as the rest of the core package moves to the core plugin from the ui plugin. This patch will be integrated, but the fix cannot be completed until the move is effected. See bug 168870.

(In reply to comment #1)
Verified with I20070223-0730 on Windows that physical deletion of the RemoteSystemsConnections project while RSE is quit is now gracefully handled.

This was considered the most critical of the 3 scenarios from comment #1, so I'm lowering severity to NORMAL for now. Scenarios 2 and 3, as well as the scenario from comment #6 should be looked at separately.
A similar problem occurs with the RemoteSystemsTempfiles project, and is logged in bug 175748.
This should be done for 2.0.1, although it is of diminished importance with the move of the profiles to the plugin state location.
